title: 6-nation talks agree on preserving leading role of civilian government in Afghanistan
text:
NEW DELHI: The key six-nation talks on stability and future of war-ravaged Afghanistan in Moscow on February 15 that involved India agreed on preserving leading role of civilian government in Kabul in the reconciliation process with Taliban underscoring Delhi's longstanding position on the issue. 

Delhi also stressed at the meet -- that included Pakistan, Iran, Afghanistan and China besides the host -- that an end to violence and terrorism is fundamental to promoting security and creating environment necessary for peace and reconciliation which is Afghan-led and owned. 

Expressing similar views a statement issued by the Russian foreign ministry said, "The participants of the consultations agreed to step up efforts to promote the advancement of internal reconciliation while preserving the leading role of Kabul and observing previously agreed principles for the armed opposition to integrate into civilian life.” 

India’s very participation at the meeting was an acknowledgement of Delhi’s key role in stablising the war-torn country less than two months after India did not figure in Russia-China-Pak trilateral meet on the issue. Delhi and Islamabad was yet again in the same room close on the heels of SAARC official-level meet in Kathmandu. India confirmed its participation at the meet when National Security Advisor Ajit K Doval was in Moscow last month. 

India expressed the hope that the initiative for these consultations, which mark a new beginning, would help promote regional cooperation for stabilising the situation in Afghanistan, protecting its unity and integrity and pursuing peace and reconciliation, according to MEA spokesperson Vikas Swarup . 

The Indian delegation at the meet without a direct to Pakistanalso stressed that it is essential “to end all forms of terrorism and extremism that beset Afghanistan and our region, and to ensure denial of territory or any other support, safe havens or sanctuaries to any terrorist group or individual in countries of our region.” 

India also underlined that it is up to the Afghan government to decide whom to engage in direct talks. These efforts can only be facilitated by friends and well-wishers of Afghanistan, the delegation noted underling Delhi’s role and goodwill there. Delhi also emphasized on arrangements of regional countries for discussing stability of Afghanistan. 

It is understood that India-USA-Afghanistan will also hold their trilateral meet on the Afghan situation in what would be first such meeting under the Trump Presidency. US President Donald Trump , however, is yet to announce his policy on Afghanistan.
